content: CHAPTER 1504 - NATIONAL AMERICAN INDIAN VETERANS, INCORPORATED: This section recognizes National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated as a corporation and grants them a federal charter under Part B of subtitle II of title 36, United States Code. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation with purposes outlined in its articles of incorporation, constitution, and bylaws, including upholding and defending the Constitution of the United States. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated (referred to as the `corporation'), is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation with purposes outlined in its articles of incorporation, constitution, and bylaws, including upholding and defending the Constitution of the United States while advocating for American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation with purposes including promoting social welfare, advocating for the needs of American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, and supporting research on their relationship with American society. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation that promotes social welfare, advocates for the needs of American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, supports research on their relationship with American society, and provides technical assistance to regional areas without veterans committees or organizations. Membership eligibility and rights are determined by the corporation's constitution and by-laws, while the board of directors operates under specific regulations. Membership in the corporation, rights, and privileges are determined by the constitution and by-laws. The board of directors' responsibilities are outlined in the corporation's bylaws and must comply with relevant laws. Officers are elected according to the constitution and bylaws, and in adherence to jurisdictional laws. Nondiscrimination is a key factor in membership conditions and board service requirements. The corporation must adhere to the laws of its jurisdiction and may not discriminate based on various factors in membership and board positions. The corporation's powers are limited to those granted in its articles of incorporation and bylaws. It has the exclusive right to certain names, seals, emblems, and badges. The corporation has the exclusive right to use specific names, seals, emblems, and badges. It is restricted from issuing stock, paying dividends, or distributing income or assets to members, officers, or directors during the charter's duration. The corporation is prohibited from distributing income or assets to members, officers, or directors during the charter's duration. Reasonable compensation and reimbursement for expenses are allowed. Loans to any officer, director, member, or employee are not permitted. The corporation cannot claim congressional approval or Federal Government authority. It must maintain its tax-exempt status as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The corporation must maintain its tax-exempt status as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It is required to keep correct and complete books and records of accounts, minutes of proceedings, and a record of members with voting rights. All books and records can be inspected by members for any proper purpose at any reasonable time. The corporation allows inspection of all books and records by members with voting rights or their agents for proper purposes. Compliance with jurisdiction laws for service of process and liability for acts of officers and agents are also outlined. The corporation is liable for the acts of its officers and agents when they act within their authority. Failure to comply with the requirements may result in the expiration of the charter.
